summary.seg: Nn.3.17 is a composite manuscript made up of two originally separate parts, each of which contains the text of three tragedies by Aeschylus (b. c. 525/524, d. c. 456/455 BC), the first of the three great Greek tragedians. The three tragedies Prometheus Bound, The Seven against Thebes and The Persians constitute the so-called 'Byzantine triad', a selections of plays among the 'canonical' ones regularly copied for studying in Byzantine schools.

The first part, sometimes referred to as Nn.3.17.1 or Nn.3.17.A was written in the 14th century; the second (Nn.3.17.2 or Nn.3.17.B) dates from the 15th. The Greek text is cited in the editions of Aeschylus as Lc for Parts I, and as Lh for Part II.

seg.note: The lower edge of Part I f. 60 is folded to conform with the present size of the manuscript (see also CUL Nn.3.14.1, ff. 121 and 154).

foliation.p: Two modern independent foliations in pencil in Arabic numerals in the top right-hand corner, recto, restarting at the beginning of Part II.
A foliation in brown ink in Greek numerals in the lower margin, recto (but α on f. 1v), starts at the beginning of Part II, from α to οη, coherently with the foliation in Arabic numerals.

binding.p: Binding with pale brown full skin covering over couched-laminate boards. The covering of the previous binding has been glued to the new. A gold rectangle is tooled on both boards and there is decorative tooling on the board edge. The title (Aeschylus) and the classmark are tooled in gold on the spine on two portions of leather painted black; the classmark is tooled on the left board as well. Marbled papers is used as pastedowns with blank leaves.
The binding was repaired by Douglas Cockerell and Son, Grantchester, December, 1964 (see f. [a] verso).

provenance.p: The three manuscripts CUL Nn.3.14, CUL Nn.3.15, and CUL Nn.3.17 belonged to the collection of the physician Richard Mead Mead, Richard, 1673-1754 (b. 1673, d. 1754), who bought them on Mount Athos or from a dealer with access to Mt Athos monasteries (see CUL Nn.3.15).

They later entered into the library of Anthony Askew Askew, Anthony, 1722-1774 (b. 1722, d. 1774), physician and book collector, who described Nn.3.17.1 and Nn.3.17.2 in CUL Nn.1.17 (readings and notes on Aeschylus transcribed on Stanley's edition, 1663) as follows: Codex MS. chartaceus in 4to. penes cels. medicum Ricardum Mead, quem ipse ab aliquot ex Monte Athos emerat. Continent Prometheum Vinctum, Persas, et Septem contra Thebas; videtur habere circiter 400 annos. Alius codex MS. chartaceus in 4to. repositus in Bibliotheca splendidissima Ricardi Mead. Continet tres priores Tragoedias, et habet circiter 30 [sic] anno. Hujus autem codicis et M 1. collactionem confecimus, AD 1744-5 Mense Februarii.

acquisition.p: After Askew's death, the manuscripts were sold by G. Leigh and J. Sotheby in the auction of his library in 1785 (Nn.3.17 Lot. n. 545), and eventually bought by Richard Farmer for Cambridge University Library. The University of Cambridge general bookplate (engraved by William Jackson in 1706-1707) was added on inside front board.

recordHist.source: Description (2019) draws on A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 4, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1861, p. 487-489.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: The older scholia on the Prometheus Bound

summary.seg: Nn.3.17.1 contains the text of the three tragedies by Aeschylus Prometheus Bound, The Seven against Thebes and The Persians, along with the scholia by the Byzantine grammarians Thomas Magistros and Demetrius Triclinius (13th-14th century).

This part belonged to a larger volume combining the so-called 'late Byzantine triads' (some selections of plays among the 'canonical' ones for studying purpose in Byzantine schools) of comedies of Aristophanes (now Nn.3.15, ff. 50r-114v), tragedies of Euripides (now Nn.3.14, ff. 1r-121v) and Aeschylus. A hypothesis of the original structure of the manuscript was made by Smith 1970, pp. 29-32.

These manuscripts are regarded as representatives of the recensions (i.e. redactions) of Aristophanes, Euripides and Aeschylus by the Byzantine grammarian Thomas Magistros Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327 (13th-14th century).

The original manuscript was initially completed by the texts of Sophocles and Pindar in the recension by Thomas Magistros in what is now Vatican City, Bibliotheca Apostolica Vaticana, Vat. gr. 1333 (+
Vat. gr. 1823 , ff. 29r-37v).

msItem.title: Vita Aeschylis (ed. Page 1972)
msItem.incipit: f. 1r πρὸς Ἱέρωνα τὸν Σικελίας τύραννον· κατά τινας μὲν ὑπὸ Ἀθηναίων κατασπουδασθεὶς, καὶ ἡσσηθεὶς νέω ὄντι τῷ Σοφοκλεῖ
msItem.explicit: f. 1r ἐποίησε δὲ δράματα ἐβδομήκοντα· ἐπὶ τούτοις σατυρικὰ ἀμφὶ τὰ πέντε· νίκας δὲ τὰς πάσας εἴληφε τρεισκαίδεκα· οὐκ ὀλίγας δὲ μετὰ τελευτὴν νίκας ἀπηνέγκατο
msItem.note: The text start on CUL Nn.3.14 f. 121v.

msItem.author: Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327
msItem.title: Hypothesis on Prometheus Bound
Thoman Argumentum Promethei Vincti (ed. Smyth 1921)
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Προμηθέως ὡς φιλανθρώπου ἐκ Διὸς κεκλοφότος τὸ πῦρ, καὶ δεδωκότος ἀνθρώποις δι’ οὗ τέχνας πάσας ἄνθρωποι εὕροντο
msItem.explicit: f. 1v εἰ μὴ τὰ μέλλοντα συμβήσεσθαι τῶ Διὶ εἴπη καὶ μὴ βουλόμενον βροντὴ καταρραγεῖσα αὐτὸν ἀφανίζει. ἡ μὲν σκηνὴ τοῦ δράματος ὑπόκειται ἐν Σκυθία ὑπὸ τὸ Καυκάσιον ὄρος. ἡ δὲ ἐπιγραφὴ τούτου Προμηθεὺς δεσμώτης
msItem.note: followed by the list of characters of the play

msItem.author: Aeschylus
msItem.title: Prometheus Bound
Prometheus Vinctus
msItem.incipit: f. 2r Χθονὸς μὲν εἰς τηλουρὸν ἥκομεν πέδον Σκύθην ἐς οἶμον, ἄβροτον εἰς ἐρημίαν
msItem.explicit: f. 30v ὦ πάντων θέμι· αἰθὴρ κοινὸν φάος εἱλίσσων, ἐσορᾶς μ’ ὡς ἔκδικα πάσχω
msItem.note: extensive scholia and interlinear glosses in red ink accompany the text

msItem.author: Tzetzes, John
msItem.title: Verse on Prometheus
In Prometheum (epigr. 1a ed. Herington 1972, p. 240 = Anthologiae Graecae Appendix IV.83, ll. 1-9, ed. Cougny 1890)
msItem.incipit: f. 30v Ἀνθ’ ὧν τὸ πῦρ δέδωκας ἀνθρώπων γένει τρύχη βία φάραγγι προσπεπηγμένος
msItem.explicit: f. 30v θεοὺς σεβάζων τοὺς παθητοὺς τὴν φύσιν, καὶ μὴ δυνατοὺς ἐκφυγεῖν τιμωρίας
msItem.note: the first two lines are repeated in cryptography on margin of f. 33v by a later hand, that also transcribed the cryptographic correspondence on f. 85v.

msItem.title: Hypothesis on The Seven Against Thebes (hyp. IV, ed. Smith 1982)
msItem.incipit: f. 31r Οἰδίπους μαθὼν ὡς ἀθέσμως συνῆν τῇ μητρὶ ἐτύφλωσεν ἑαυτόν· οἱ δὲ παῖδες αὐτοῦ Ἐτεοκλῆς καὶ Πολυνείκης
msItem.explicit: f. 31r Αἰσχύλος δὲ ἕτερον τῶν ἑπτὰ Ἐτέοκλον ἀντὶ Ἀδράστου προσθείς· ἐγράφη δὲ ἡ ἱστορία αὕτη ἐξ ἀρχῆς κατὰ λεπτὸν ἐν Φοινίσσαις Εὐριπίδου
msItem.note: followed by the list of characters of the play

msItem.author: Aeschylus
msItem.title: The Seven Against Thebes
Septem contra Thebes
msItem.rubric: f. 32r Αἰσχύλου τῶν ἑπτὰ ἐπὶ Θήβαις
msItem.incipit: f. 32r Κάδμου πολῖται χρὴ λέγειν τὰ καίρια ὅστις φυλάσσει πρᾶγος ἐν πρύμνη πόλεως
msItem.explicit: f. 60v κύματι φωτῶν κατακλυσθῆναι τὰ μάλιστα
msItem.finalRubric: f. 60v τέλος Αἰσχύλου τῶν ἑπτὰ ἐπὶ Θήβαις
msItem.note: extensive scholia and interlinear glosses in red and brown ink accompany the text.

msItem.title: Verse on The Seven Against Thebes (= Anthologiae Graecae Appendix IV.84, ll. 3-4, ed. Cougny 1890)
msItem.incipit: f. 60v δεινοπροσωπήσασα τέμνεται ξίφει δυὰς ἀδελφῶν ἡ μιαιφονωτάτη

msItem.author: Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327
msItem.title: Hypothesis on The Persians
Thoman Argumentum in Persas (ed. Massa Positano 1963)
msItem.rubric: f. 61r Ἡ τούτου τοῦ δράματος ὑπόθεσίς ἐστιν ἡ κατὰ τῆς Ἑλλάδος ἐπιστρατεία τοῦ Ξέρξου καὶ αἱ ἐκεῖθεν δυστυχίαι καὶ ἀποχώρησις. τὰ δὲ πρόσωπα χορὸς γερόντων περὶ τὰ βασίλεια τοῦ Ξέρξου, Ἄτοσσα ἡ τοῦ Ξέρξου μήτηρ ἡ καὶ προφοιβασθεῖσα δι’ ὀνειράτων τὴν τούτου ἥτταν· ἄγγελος πάντα διασαφῶν, εἴδωλον Δαρείου καὶ Ξέρξης. πᾶσα δὲ ἡ ἱστορία τοῦ Ξέρξου ἔχει οὕτως
msItem.incipit: f. 61r Ἱππίας ὁ Πεισιστράτου τύραννος ὢν Ἀθηναίων ἐξέπεσε τῆς τυραννίδος. ἐλθὼν οὖν παρὰ Πέρσας ἱκετεύει Δαρεῖον στρατεύειν κατ’ Ἀθηνῶν, καὶ ὃς πείθεται, ὡς Ἀριστείδης φησίν
msItem.explicit: f. 61v ἔσχε δὲ τὴν μὲν ἐν Σαλαμῖνι τῆς ναυμαχίας νίκην Θεμιστοκλῆς· τὴν δὲ ἐν Πλαταία τοῦ πεζοῦ νίκην, Παυσανίας ὁ Λακεδαιμονίων στρατηγός.

msItem.author: Aeschylus
msItem.title: The Persians (ll. 1-1065)
Persae
msItem.incipit: f. 62r Τάδε μὲν Περσῶν τῶν οἰχομένων Ἑλλάδ’ ἐς αἶαν πιστὰ καλεῖται
msItem.explicit: f. 88v ἄπριγδ’ ἄπριγδα μάλα γοεδνά. διαίνου δ’ ὄσσε
msItem.note: extensive scholia and interlinear glosses in brown ink accompany the text

support.material: ff. 1r-88v Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Crown ( 40 60 ) near the gutter comparable to Mošin-Traljić 1957, Filigranes des XIIIe et XIVe ss, Couronne 3200-5 dated 1319-1324.

collation.p:
Part I is now made up of 8 quaternions, one bifolium and 8 binions, with different folios cut or replaced without any loss of text. This condition is due to the breaking up of the original manuscript and the further interventions of binding and conservation.
Quire 18-4 ff. 1r-4v (the first half of this quaterion is made up of Nn.3.14.1, ff. 118-121, without any loss of text between Nn.3.14.1, f. 121v and Nn.3.17.1, f. 1r)
Quires 2-38 ff. 5r-20v
Quire 48-2 ff. 21r-26v
Quire 52 ff. 27r-28v
Quires 6-88 ff. 29r-52v
Quire 98-2 ff. 53r-58v
Quires 10-154 ff. 59r-81v
Quire 164-1 ff. 82r-84v
Quire 174 ff. 85r-88v

signatures.p: A quire signature in Greek numerals in brown ink from the original manuscript (Nn.3.15.1 Part Ib + Nn.3.14 Part I + Nn.3.17.1) remains on the lower margin of f. 60v: λϛ. This signature survives on the lower margin of the folio along with a drawing (Arabic?). It seems that the margin was folded rather than cut to conform with the present size of the manuscript when the manuscript was bound, in order to preserve the drawing and the signature (cf. Smith 1970).

condition.p: In fair general condition. Leaves are yellow with age; there are stains, extended worm holes in the upper margins. The last folios (ff. 85-88) have lost considerable portions of the margins, which have been reconstructed.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-88v: 160 65
Scholia and prefatory materials that accompany the main texts have a very variable number of lines per page, and are arranged in an orderly manner.

handNote.p: Hand A: ff. 2r-30v, ff. 32r-60v, and ff. 62r-88v
The main texts are written in a mixed minuscule in an upright, scribal hand, in brown ink script.

There is a marked variation in letter size. Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are rare, and usually appearing only at the end of lines. Breathings are curved and mute iota is rarely used.

The small majuscules beta, gamma, eta, kappa phi are present. Gamma and tau are often high. The majuscule beta has often a curled bilobate shape and unlike the other parts of the original manuscript (see below), here it presents, especially if in the first line of text, an extremely enlarged shape in the upper margin, with inclusions of the following letters (e.g. f. 27v). Epsilon is both regular minuscule and lunate. The sigma telikon is not present.
Phi-rho ligature is in two strokes and overlapping. Ligatures of tau with alpha or omicron are from the bottom, in a characteristic Z-shape.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper point, lower comma and full stop.
Tails are frequently flourished into the lower and upper margins.
This hand is present in CUL Nn.3.14 (ff. 1r-121v) and CUL Nn.3.17.1 (ff. 1r-88v), and designated as Hand B of the original manuscript (see Günther 1995).
Hand B: Ioannes Zeianos: scholia.

The names of Ioannes Zeianos (PLP n. 6516) appears on f. 60v in a monocondylion and within a tail on the lower margin of CUL Nn.3.15.1, f. 89r, as owner of the original manuscript: ἰωάννης ὁ ζειανὸς ὁ κτήτωρ τοῦδε τοῦ βιβλίου. He also designated as Hand C of the original manuscript (see Günther 1995)
His hand presents the main characteristics of the Fettaugen mode, performed with order and clarity, with numerous inclusions, large letters combined with others of smaller module.
On the identity of Ioannes Zeianos, see Smith 1992, p. 223-225.
Hand C: Vita Aeschylis and hypothesis ff. 1r-1v, 31r, 61r, and the interlinear glosses in red ink
The hypotesis and the Vita Aeschylis are written in a mixed minuscule in an upright, scribal hand, in brown ink script.
There is a marked variation in letter size. Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are common. Breathings are curved and mute iota is rarely used.
It seems to follow the same model as Zeianos, but in a very small size and with a much smaller number of ligatures. The transcribed folios have a yellow grid above the writing.
This hand is present in CUL Nn.3.14, and CUL Nn.3.15.1, and designated as Hand D of the original manuscript (see Günther 1995).

decoNote.p: The beginning of the texts on ff. 1r, 2r, 31r, 32r, 61r and 62r are preceded by headpieces in red ink with weave decoration, or rectangular shape with small palms. The headpiece on f. 2r is made up of interwoven circles with bird figures and floral motifs inside. The headpiece of f. 62r has been copied by a reader on the margin.
Some small tailpieces have been added in brown ink by a different hand: 30v, 60v (a snake).

decoDesc.decoNote: The texts on ff. 1r, 2r, 32r, 62r, begin with ornate initials, outlined in red ink.

additions.p: One or more readers have added some sketches: Orestes on 71v, 72bis r, 83v, and a ship on f. 5r.

origin.p: The manuscript can be located at the Monastery of the Dionysiou of Mount Athos, and thanks to the name of Zeianos and the textual characteristics, it is possible to assume that it arrived there from Thessaloniki, and that it was set up in the scriptorium of Demetrius Triclinius Triclinius, Demetrius , or in a scriptorium connected with him.
The characteristics of the script and the watermarks suggest that it was produced during the early 14th century, probably before 1325.

summary.seg: Part II was written probably in the second half of 15th century and added to Part I before Mead's purchase without any manifest intention of supplementing the text: the three tragedies of Part I are repeated. The scholia are in thomano-triclinian recension.

msItem.title: Vita Aeschylis (ed. Page 1972)
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Αἰσχύλος ὁ τραγικὸς γένει μὲν ἦν Ἀθηναῖος· Ἐλευσίνιος τῶν δήμων· υἱὸς Εὐφορίωνος· Κυναιγείρου ἀδελφός καὶ Ἀμεινίου
msItem.explicit: f. 1v ἐποίησε δὲ δράματα ἐβδομήκοντα· ἐπὶ τούτοις σατυρικὰ ἀμφὶ τὰ πέντε· νίκας δὲ τὰς πάσας εἴληφε τρεισκαίδεκα· οὐκ ὀλίγας δὲ μετὰ τελευτὴν νίκας ἀπηνέγκατο

msItem.author: Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327
msItem.title: Hypothesis on Prometheus Bound
Thoman Argumentum Promethei Vincti (ed. Smyth 1921)
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Προμηθέως ἐκ Διὸς κεκλοφότος τὸ πῦρ καὶ δεδωκότος ἀνθρώποις δι’ οὗ τέχνας πάσας ἄνθρωποι εὕροντο
msItem.explicit: f. 1v εἰ μὴ τὰ μέλλοντα συμβήσεσθαι τῶ Διὶ εἴπη· καὶ μὴ βουλόμενον βροντὴ καταρραγεῖσα αὐτὸν ἀφανίζει

msItem.author: Aeschylus
msItem.title: Prometheus Bound
Prometheus Vinctus
msItem.incipit: f. 2r Χθονὸς μὲν εἰς τηλουρὸν ἥκομεν πέδον Σκύθην ἐς οἶμον, ἄβροτον εἰς ἐρημίαν
msItem.explicit: f. 29r ὦ πάντων αἰθὴρ κοινὸν φάος εἱλίσσων, ἐσορᾶις μ’ ὡς ἔκδικα πάσχω
msItem.note: preceded by the list of characters of the play
extensive scholia and interlinear glosses accompany the text

msItem.title: Hypothesis on The Seven Against Thebes (hyp. II, ed. Smith 1982, p. 1 l. 10 - p. 11 l. 20)
msItem.incipit: f. 29v Λάιος ἐβασίλευσε ἐν Θήβαις· ἔσχε δὲ τὴν Ἰοκάστην γυναῖκα, παῖδα δὲ οὐκ ἐποίει. ἀγανακτῶν τοίνυν ἐπὶ τῇ ἀτεκνίᾳ ἀπῆλθεν εἰς Πυθὼ ἐρωτήσων τί ἂν ποιήσας παιδοποιήση ἐξήνεγκε δὲ τὸ χρηστήριον· μὴ σπεῖρε τέκνων ἄλοκα Λάιε βία δαιμόνων. λαβὼν δὲ τὸν χρησμὸν καὶ ἀπελθὼν The beginnig of the text is partly illegible
msItem.explicit: f. 29v ὕστερον δὲ μαθὼν καὶ νοήσας τὸ ἀνόμημα ὃ ἔδρασεν ἐτύφλωσεν ἑαυτόν τοῖς δὲ εἰρημένοις παισὶν αὐτοῦ ὁ γοῦν Πολυνείκης

msItem.author: Aeschylus
msItem.title: The Seven Against Thebes
Septem contra Thebes
msItem.rubric: f. 30r προλογίζει Ἐτεοκλῆς παρασκευάζωντον τὸν δῆμον τῶν Θηβαίων εἰς φρουρὰν τῆς πόλεως
msItem.incipit: f. 30r Κάδμου πολῖται· χρὴ λέγειν τὰ καίρια ὅς, τις φυλάσσει πρᾶγος ἐν πρύμνη πόλεως
msItem.explicit: f. 55r κύματι φωτῶν κατακλυσθῆναι τὰ μάλιστα
msItem.note: preceded by the list of characters of the play
extensive scholia and interlinear glosses accompany the text

msItem.author: Aeschylus
msItem.title: The Persians (ll. 1-938)
Persae
msItem.incipit: f. 56r Τάδε μὲν Περσῶν τῶν οἰχομένων Ἑλλάδ’ ἐς αἶαν πιστὰ καλεῖται
msItem.explicit: f. 78v πρόσφθογγόν σοι νόστου ταύταν κακοφάτιδα βοάν κακομέλετον ἰὰν Μαριανδυνοῦ
msItem.note: preceded by the list of characters of the play
etensive scholia and interlinear glosses accompany the text

support.material: ff. 1r-78v. Non-watermarked paper, folded in quarto.

collation.p:
Part II of the manuscript consists of one binion, 2 ternions, 4 quaternions, 3 quinions and 2 bifolia:
Quire 186 ff. 1r-6v
Quires 19-2010 ff. 7r-24v
Quire 216 ff. 25r-30v
Quire 2210-1 ff. 31r-39v
Quire 232 ff. 40r-41v
Quire 244 ff. 42r-45v
Quire 252 ff. 46r-47v
Quire 268 ff. 48r-55v
Quires 27-288 ff. 56r-71v
Quire 298-1 ff. 72r-78v

signatures.p: There is a folio signature in Greek numerals from α to οη in brown ink in the lower margin of the rectos (except for the first α on f. 1v)

condition.p: In fair general condition. Leaves are yellow with age; there are stains, extended wormholes in the upper margins. The outer margin of f. 67 have been cut and reconstructed.

layoutDesc.layout:
Ff. 1r-78v: 160 70
Scholia and prefatory materials that accompany the main texts have a very variable number of lines per page, and are arranged in an orderly manner.

handNote.p: Hand D: ff. 1r-78v
The main texts and the scholia are written in a mixed minuscule upright or slanting slightly to the right, in dark brown ink. The ductus is cursive.

The variation in letter size is not marked. Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are rare, and usually appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are curved and mute iota is rarely used.

The small majuscules beta, gamma, eta, kappa, lambda, pi phi are present. Gamma and tau are often high. Alpha is often enlarged; epsilon is both regular minuscule and lunate. The open shape of theta is present only if ligated. The sigma has both lunate and regular shapes, but the sigma telikon is not present. Omega is closed and often ligated to the previous letter from below.
Double lambda ligature is overlapping. Ligatures of rho with alpha or omicron are from the bottom.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper point, lower comma and full stop.
The same hand has written the interlinear glosses in smaller size.

decoNote.p: The beginning of the texts on ff. 1r, 2r are preceded by weave decorations, or rectangular shape in red ink with floral motifs. The lists of characters on ff. 30r and 56r are surrounded by a frame with stylized leaves in red ink.
Two tailpieces in black and brown ink by two different hands are present on f. 55r.

decoDesc.decoNote: Enlarged ornamental initials, outlined in red ink on ff. 1r, 1v, 2r, 30r and 56r.

additions.p: One or more readers have added two small sketches: a dog on f. 7v, a face on f. 55v.

origin.p: The characteristics of the script suggest that it was produced in the second half of 15th century, probably after 1475.
